description: This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.
name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments:
This course is an examination of the factors (both internal and external) that influence people's behavior in a buying situation. Course objectives are: (1) to provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, integrating theories from psychology, sociology, and economics; (2) to provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions; and (3) to introduce behavioral research approaches. 

Students had mixed reviews about the course content. Some found it to be “a great class” that “taught a lot about marketing tactics.” Furthermore, students mentioned that they “learned a lot theoretically” while also getting “the chance to apply course concepts in a case study as a final project.” However, some students found that concepts were “reduced to the most basic simplification.” Many students felt that the material overlapped with content from other marketing and psychology courses. 

Students said Professor Miron-Shatz genuinely cared about the success of her students, and some noted that she had great examples and illustrations to demonstrate concepts. Some students claimed she was very accessible, while others mentioned she did not have regular office hours, making it difficult to ask questions. Finally, many mentioned that the subject matter “wasn't communicated as clearly as it could have been.” Several mentioned that lectures were dry and not engaging. 

The workload for the class consisted of one group project, one final, and four case write-ups throughout the semester. The group project, which consists of each group having an external client from SBDC, was found to be very interesting, although it only counted for a small proportion of the grade. Some claimed that the exam was difficult and that the cases were “very long and technical.” Overall, though, students felt that the workload was fair and manageable.
